KPI name and description:
Quality of narrative reporting
   
   This indicator assesses the quality of the quarterly narrative programme report to DFID, based on the specified criteria:
   1.  Reports are submitted by the agreed deadline and in the correct template                                                                                                                               
   2. Report answers the key 'exam questions' without superfluous or duplicative content ; reports are well-structured in a logical and coherent order, written in "one voice", with effective use of headings and sub-headings no longer than 40 pages for main body of report                                                                                                 
   3. Conclusions are supported by data, high-level analysis and evidence as can be expected in a concise report                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             
   4. Use of plain English with very few spelling and grammatical errors, avoidance of jargon and no use of acronyms without written in full when first used                                                                                                                         
   5. Effective use of diagrams, graphs and tables to illustrate
   6. Response to feedback on written deliverables is submitted on time: usually 2 weeks for quarterly reporting and 1 week for other products, unless otherwise agreed and as recorded in the deliverable tracker.

Contract title and description: Strengthening the teaching of primary school mathematics in Malawi
KPI name and description:
KPI2
   Set of  submitted quarterly milestones are of good quality as gauged by the Education Adviser (Technical criterion, weight at 50%) and by the Ministry of Education Director of Quality Assurance (government embedding and sustainability criterion, weight at 50%)
   The milestones are of good quality- i.e., technically strong and well embedded into government systems, facilitating government take-up and sustainability”
   1. Technical criterion- The Education Adviser will gauge the quality of submitted milestones as a whole (the set of milestones as a proxy for progress in implementation, not one by one) based on national and international evidence and given analysis of constraints and opportunities; it will also consider Value for Money and innovation. The Adviser will write a short memo accompanying the score (good/approaching target/requires improvement/inadequate).  
    2. Government embedding and sustainability criterion: the Director of Quality Assurance, who is the government coordinator for the programme, will have a quarterly meeting with FCDO which will be minuted, and score whether the set of milestones are embedding the programme in government systems and are considering sustainability (good/approaching target/requires improvement/inadequate).  
   Good: both technical and government embedding scores are good or one is good and one is approaching target
   Approaching target: both scores are approaching target or one is approaching target and one requires improvement.
   Requires improvement: both scores require improvement or one is requiring improvement and one is inadequate  
   Inadequate: Both scores are inadequate
Good target: Both technical and government embedding scores are good or one is good and one is approaching target
Comments: Actions were agreed and taken as follows: Cambridge Education allowed the technical director to step down and instead set up three technical teams to lead on revision of workbooks and teacher guides, teachers training model and monitoring and evaluation strategy. The MoE and MIE have taken the lead to ensure institutionalisation and embedding into government system, which is the key concern around quality milestones.

KPI name and description:
KPI1
   100% of the agreed contractual quarterly milestones have been submitted within the timeline of one week before end of quarter and have been approved by the SRO.  
   •	Milestones are submitted to FCDO at least one week before end of the quarter and subsequently approved by FCDO within one week of receipt.
   •	When any milestone is not met, quarterly reporting includes clear and concise narrative on areas on- and off-track; reasons for delays (within and outside project team control) and assessment of effects on project outputs and outcomes. 
   •	Where milestones are not achieved due to reasons outside project team control, CE will communicate/ provide justification within two weeks of the start of the quarter, and subject to FCDO SRO sign-off will not be included as part of bullet point 1.
   •	Milestones will be reviewed, and feedback shared by FCDO SRO within one week following receipt, and will allow for a one-week response time from CE following which a final scoring will be provided.
   Good: all milestones submitted on time and approved
   Approaching target: one milestone is not submitted or approved  within the deadline.
   Requires improvement: two Milestones are not submitted or approved within the deadline.
   Inadequate: more than two milestones are not submitted or approved within the deadline.
Good target: All milestones are submitted on time and approved by SRO within the deadline.

KPI name and description: Maximising value for money: an updated value for money assessment should be submitted with the supplier quarterly reports to indicate that the supplier has proactively sought out and (where possible) implemented opportunities to deliver the project more efficiently, effectively or economically in the quarter under review. Scoring is evaluated as follows: if the quarterly VfM assessment evidences the identification of at least 3 new opportunities for the year of which at least 3 new opportunities are being implemented then the KPI scores 6. If the quarterly VfM assessment evidences identification of at least 2 new opportunities for the year of which 1 is being implemented then the KPI scores 3. If no new opportunities are identified, the KPI scores 0.
Good target: 3 annual VfM opportunities identified, out of which at least 2 are being implemented

It’s hoped all the SLA’s will be being achieved by mid-April 2023.

Contract title and description: MSS/107 - MTU Diesel Generator Support
KPI name and description: Procurement Lead Time
Good target: Equal to or higher than 97 percent
Comments:
Rolls-Royce Solutions continue to delivery the majority of spare parts well ahead of schedule.  Due to the volume of spare parts being order by the MoD, one late delivery of a part automatically impacts Rolls-Royce Solutions KPI negatively.  At this point of the contract Rolls-Royce Solutions were assuming a greater volume of spare parts, however due to delays of other projects outside of Rolls-Royce Solutions control this has been further delayed.  Therefore Rolls-Royce Solutions has a negative impact on three fronts, financial impact due to contract KPI’s, financial impact due to reduced number of parts being ordered and the financial impact due to high levels of inflation (fixed cost project).

Rolls-Royce Solutions will continue to work with the MoD to accelerate procurement lead times and improve the KPI during these challenging global supply chain periods.

Provision of an interior cleaning service in accordance with the common cleaning standards.
Scored Monthly:
Green = Number of material non-compliances is 0 and number of minor non-compliances is less than 10.
Amber = Number of material non-compliances is between 1 and 2 and/or the number of minor non-compliances is 10 or more and less than 20.
Red = Number of material non-compliances is 3 or more, and/or the number of minor non-compliances is 20 or more.

Contract title and description: RECRUITING PARTNERING CONTRACT-HQLF2/1739
KPI name and description: Recruitment of Regular Soldiers: Demand/Baseline Recruit Allocation Plan percentage
Comments: KPI 1 reflects Capita’s performance in recruiting soldiers to meet specific monthly targets across a wide range of job roles. With regards KPI 1, the contractor’s ability to achieve recruitment targets during Q3 has been impacted by the ongoing buoyant National jobs market that shows a high vacancy rate, with job postings some 43% above pre-pandemic levels, which means that Capita with the Army offer is competing against many other potential employers to attract recruits to fill these vacancies, whilst at the same time there has been a reduction in the size of the eligible target audience due to changing social demographics. To address these challenges,  Capita is working closely with the Army to drive a number of initiatives seeking to increase overall volumes and further improve conversion rates; these include the recent launch of a new Army website to attract potential candidates, and optimisation of current marketing activities to maximise engagement with main target audiences and generally raise the profile of the Army as an attractive job choice
